Comment:
This is a game from the Snowdragons team invitational tournament. By the time this game is played both players have resigned from the team already.  
Nevertheless Shakechess is the undisputed leader of the tournament with a 100% score. The 350 points rating gap also helps to keep white's expectations at a modest level...

So far this opening was a Pirc (B07), but Be3 is not in the books.... The newspapers would write that Radboud had prepared this new move against his Angstgegner Shakechess....there is no lesser truth !!

Admitted, Gameknot's 'game db' is a big help to come out of the opening reasonably against a higher rated player.
Seems harmless still, but black is setting up a trap.
The trap is to have white put his Queen and King on a diagonal.
The trap is to have white put his Queen and King on a diagonal.
The trap is to have white put his Queen and King on a diagonal.

Threatens Bxd4 to win the Queen. At the same time threatens at b2. 
Or, how you can own the center and still be in immediate trouble !!

Threatens Bxd4 to win the Queen. At the same time threatens at b2. 
Or, how you can own the center and still be in immediate trouble !!

Cuts off the Bishop's diagonal. If Black decides to take on b2 then 13. Bxa6, bxa6. 14. Nd5 and White is still very much in the game.

Note: Radboud's rating at this point = 1714, highest ever.

When I look at my position I like that I control the center, however with b3 that position is undermined, the Knight on c3 is not covered  and the Knight on d4 is weak being covered by the Queen on a diagonal with the King.... The pawn on e5 is badly defended too.

When I look at my position I like that I control the center, however with b3 that position is undermined, the Knight on c3 is not covered  and the Knight on d4 is weak being covered by the Queen on a diagonal with the King.... The pawn on e5 is badly defended too.

Immediate threat is the Knight at d4. That piece is becoming black's target because it is pinned in front of the white Queen unhappily in the diagonal to the King. 

I looked at 15. Ncb5 but follows 15...., Nxc5. 16. Nxc5, Qxe3  or 16. Bxc5, Qxd4.
I looked at 15. Rf4 to cover the Knight and develop an attack of my own, but those ambitions would quickly be killed by 15...., Ne6.

16......, Be6? 17. Kh1 to make the Knight on d4 free to move.

Was Qg5 better? To save the pawn on e5.

I am afraid of black's Nc3.

Wins the pawn and builds even more pressure on the Knight on d4.
The idea is to get compensation for the material that is about to be lost on the center of the board.

Black later claimed that this move was the one losing the game for white, but really I don't see any way to save the Knight on d4. I think the position was lost earlier.
Maybe 14. b3 was bad already, weakening the support in the center. 14. Rb1 was another option to save the b-pawn.

Is Nxc3 better? The idea of Qxe7 is to threaten Rf8 , Rxf8 and Qxf8  .

Not 21...., Bxa1? 22. Rf8 , Rxf8. 23. Qxf8  .

This time without check, but Bf5 blocks the white rook on the f-file and connects the black rooks. If the game wasn't over yet then it is now.
